ratings.comment: CLASSIC example of the absent-minded professor. He digresses a lot during class, so is not worth it to go to lecture. I took him for a lab, so I was fortunate enough to have had a wonderful IA. However, Day made the quizzes and they were generally very unpredictable despite having been given a problem set.

Professor day was very scattered throughout his portion of the course. While he seems extremely knowledgeable he has a difficult time putting his knowledge out in a teaching format. The out of class course work was loaded right before the exam so there was no time for problem review and he takes FOREVER to grade

He is unarguably the best professor ever in my college career. His lecture is super-interesting. I am usually tired due to the lack of sleep, but his lectures are so interesting that it's hard to fall asleep (I fell asleep in other boring classes). He sparked my passion for genetics in me, which is the only reason I chose to major in genetics!

Chris Day was BY FAR the best professor I've had here. The class is really difficult but if you go to office hours it will help you immensely - he is also really flexible to meet whenever you need help, so that's good too. His accent is a bit tricky to understand sometimes, but overall he is a great professor and a great person.

by far one of the most scattered and unclear professors you will ever encounter in your college experience. Any and all good reviews for this man baffle me. His lecture style is essentially an impromptu conversation with the class. as a result, concepts are unclear and many test questions go off of random and highly specific facts from slides.

i thought he was very interesting to listen to, he really wants students to understand what he's talking about, but doesn't understands that its hard to speak up in a large lecture, so sometimes some things can be unclear.  wished he would do more practice problems to get a sense of what kind of answers he was looking for.  glad for the notecard!

Chris is a really nice guy who is very passionate about teaching and his students. His manner of teaching is very casual, and some students will prefer that while others will struggle. I think he's mainly interested in getting his students to think critically. He's good humored and willing to help answer questions.

Since this is a capstone class for those interested in genetics or any biosciences, it's very application-orientated. Chris does a good job with his lectures although we don't usually finish. The reason due to the amount of discussion he goes into. His study is on plants, so he quite knowledgeable in the topics we cover involving plants.

Professor Day has been my favorite professor at Madison so far. He really cares about his students and is incredibly passionate about genetics. The only downside is that his lectures can be disorganized, but if you do the study guides and attend review lectures, you can get an A in the class fairly easily.

Lecture content is very disorganized and his lectures in general are not clear. This class may be difficult if you have never taken a biology class before. In addition, I would say you are likely to learn more from a better professor.

Chris is an amazing person.  He really cares about his students and wants them to succeed.  His tests are pretty tough, but an A in his class is an 85%, so it is definitely possible!  I found his lectures to be really confusing at times though, and not sure what he expects us to know for the exam.

I went into this class with almost no knowledge of biology chemistry, and this class would have been much easier with a chem background.  Nonetheless, my TA was awesome and Professor Day knows his stuff, you just have to ask when you need something clarified.
His lectures are interesting but not very organized. The tests and assignments are often confusing due to lack of detailed explanation about the topics. Very nice guy though.
He's pretty disorganized and gets off topic easily. You can tell he loves genetics but jumps around to different areas frequently.

Dr Day is a bit disorganized but he is far and away the best professor at Madison. He cares a lot about his students and if you put in the effort you will get an A in the class. He is happy to answer questions at any time outside of class, will make time to see anyone and is incredibly knowledgeable in the genetics field. I absolutely love him.

Chris is awesome! At first, he came in during the beginning of the second midterm contents. I wasn't too sure of him because he was new to me at the time and I was just getting used to the first professor who switched over. But Chris is a great guy, he's willing to help but only if you make the initiative to go out and see him and make time.
He's a great guy and very passionate about genetics and biology in general.
He's very friendly and cares about his students.  He's sometimes a bit confusing in lecture, but overall pretty coherent.

Dr. Day is a great guy and he truly wants his students to succeed. He is extremely intelligent and passionate about genetics. Lectures can be hard to follow, he will move fast, but the class is manageable if you're willing to put the work in.

Professor Day is super passionate about genetics and really cares about his students, he wants everyone to succeed. That being said, the class isn't easy and sometimes lecture is hard to follow. There is no required textbook, so going to lecture is super important and I would recommend getting a supplementary textbook for misunderstandings.
Absolutely loved his Genetics class.  He's so helpful and passionate about what he does.  The class is incredibly interesting and easy to follow.

He is a professor who genuinely cares about his students, and will go out of his way to help make life easier (printing off slides, postpones homework) and to also make sure they are doing okay in the class.  Lecture can be a little confusing but the discussion sections help immensely.  My favorite professor!

Really knowledgeable professor.  You can tell that he's really interested in the student's learning/comprehending of the material.  One of my favorites at the University.  That said, I hated the class (566 - genetics capstone)
Like his accent,easy understanding.He taughts really interesting and responsible.though the exams are easy but the rating is unfair, especially the part of TA rating
Overall one of my favorite professors.  Very fair grader and super willing to work with students and answer their questions.

Sometimes forgets to send reminders. Very approachable - he even helped me with my genetics homework, even though that wasn't the focus of the class! Overall, he grades by looking at how you matured vs. homework.

Very easy going. Gets side-tracked reemphasizing a topic or branching off in related material. Little homework. Has difficulty teaching, so you'll have to work hard at trying to decipher lecture--taking good notes--when its presented. Much of the course (exams) was taking knowledge from lecture/discussion and being able to logically apply it.
Very disorganized. Not always clear on what he expects. He forgets things frequently. Although he was just a leader for one of the sections, a bit much was expected for one credit.

very nice man but HORRIBLE professor! Someone asked him a question in lecture and his response was that he had to "read that section in the book again" because he had no idea! he wrote all over the board and never actually explained anything! way too hard to be an intro class for non-science majors.. don't take it unless you did really well in chem

Classic case of nice guy but terrible teacher. Lectures were always a very broad overview of the course materials and the exams were incredibly confusing and were 50% things we never learned. This is the most ridiculous 100 level, non-science major class ever. A girl in my discussion did well on her exam because she had taken biochem 500-level

He was impossible to communicate with, and very disorganized.  The class said there were no prerequisites, but you needed a background at least in chemistry to understand what was going on.  Not an intro course.  He put things on the exam that we had not learned in lecture.  Do NOT take his class, especially if you aren't a science major!

Just terrible. Gives incorrect and incomplete examples in class and can't explain or fix them. Does a poor job of answering student questions. Pray that you have a good TA, and go to every office hour available. The class average for every exam is failing, but he does give a slight curve.

Very unorganized. He punishes you for completing homework early because he consistently is emailing you with changes to homework. Avoid if at all possible. This is the hardest 3 credit class I have ever taken... It takes up about 15-18 hours of out-of-class study per week and am still near the middle of the pack in terms of grades (class avg. is D)

VERY disorganized.  Jumps around in lecture.  Cannot seem to reiterate the material for beginning level students.  Questions are very ambiguous.  Don't take this class if you have no prior genetics experience!

He is very unorganized, he showed up the first exam 15 min late because he went to the wrong building. Going to his lecture was painful and he taught nothing. He wrote all over the board and it made no sense.  He also promised a study guide for the final and didn't send it out till 1 AM the day of the exam. However, he is nice and loves his student

Mediocre professor.  He tends to jump around a lot in lecture and makes the material more complicated than what it seems.  Outside of class, he provides a lot of help, but some things he talks about is just useless so you'll have to figure out a way to word your questions.  If no one else is teaching genetics 160, make good use of your TA.
In general, very nice and willing to help you outside of class. Sometimes disorganized, but in the end it all comes together. Not very difficult for a genetics class.

Trying to follow his lectures is annoying, like the mosquito that keeps buzzing in your ear. No matter what you do, the irritation is always there. Very disorganized. Otherwise, interesting and tries to help out the students.
Very dedicated Professor.  He is one that cares for his students and even set up a student board to get feedback on how we are doing.  Excellent!
I was somewhat interested in the topics that he taught in before entering his class.  But he was an excellent lecturer and greatly stimulated my interest in these topics.
Cooky Englishman...but a good prof.  His teaching style can be a bit scattered but he gets his point across and in the end you will undertand the material.
